section: de.py fcmaes/de.py Go to the documentation of this file.00001 # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- 00002 """ 00003 ============================================================================= 00004 00005 Fast CMA-ES - version 1.6.11 00006 00007 (c) 2025 – Dietmar Wolz 00008 (c) 2025 – Latitude 00009 00010 License: MIT 00011 00012 File: 00013 - de.py 00014 00015 Description: 00016 - Numpy based implementation of Differential Evolution using the DE/best/1 strategy. 00017 Derived from its C++ counterpart [2]. 00018 00019 Uses three deviations from the standard DE algorithm: 00020 a) temporal locality introduced in [3] to improve convergence speed. 00021 b) reinitialization of individuals based on their age. 00022 c) oscillating CR/F parameters. 00023 00024 You may keep parameters F and Cr at their defaults since this implementation works well with the given settings for most problems, 00025 since the algorithm oscillates between different F and Cr settings. 00026 00027 The filter parameter is inspired by "Surrogate-based Optimisation for a Hospital Simulation" 00028 [4] where a machine learning classifier is used to 00029 filter candidate solutions for DE. A filter object needs to provide function add(x, y) to enable learning and 00030 a predicate is_improve(x, x_old, y_old) used to decide if function evaluation of x is worth the effort. 00031 00032 The ints parameter is a boolean array indicating which parameters are discrete integer values. This 00033 parameter was introduced after observing non optimal results for the ESP2 benchmark problem: 00034 [5] 00035 If defined it causes a "special treatment" for discrete variables: They are rounded to the next integer value and 00036 there is an additional mutation to avoid getting stuck at local minima. This behavior is specified by the internal 00037 function _modifier which can be overwritten by providing the optional modifier argument. If modifier is defined, 00038 ints is ignored. 00039 00040 Use the C++ implementation combined with parallel retry instead for objective functions which are fast to evaluate. 00041 For expensive objective functions (e.g. machine learning parameter optimization) use the workers 00042 parameter to parallelize objective function evaluation. This causes delayed population update. 00043 It is usually preferrable if popsize > workers and workers = mp.cpu_count() to improve CPU utilization. 00044 00045 00046 Authors: 00047 - Dietmar Wolz 00048 - romain.despoullains@latitude.eu 00049 - corentin.generet@latitude.eu 00050 00051 References: 00052 - [1] https://github.com/dietmarwo/fast-cma-es 00053 - [2] https://github.com/dietmarwo/fast-cma-es/blob/master/_fcmaescpp/deoptimizer.cpp 00054 - [3] https://www.researchgate.net/publication/309179699_Differential_evolution_for_protein_folding_optimization_based_on_a_three-dimensional_AB_off-lattice_model 00055 - [4] https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3449726.3463283 00056 - [5] https://github.com/AlgTUDelft/ExpensiveOptimBenchmark/blob/master/expensiveoptimbenchmark/problems/DockerCFDBenchmark.py 00057 00058 Documentation: 00059 - 00060 00061 00062 ============================================================================= 00063 """ 00064 00065 00066 import numpy as np 00067 import math, sys 00068 from time import time 00069 import ctypes as ct 00070 from numpy.random import Generator, PCG64DXSM 00071 from scipy.optimize import OptimizeResult, Bounds 00072 from fcmaes.evaluator import Evaluator, is_debug_active 00073 import multiprocessing as mp 00074 from collections import deque 00075 from loguru import logger 00076 from typing import Optional, Callable, Tuple, Union 00077 from numpy.typing import ArrayLike 00078 00079 def minimize(fun: Callable[[ArrayLike], float], 00080 dim: Optional[int] = None, 00081 bounds: Optional[Bounds] = None, 00082 popsize: Optional[int] = 31, 00083 max_evaluations: Optional[int] = 100000, 00084 workers: Optional[int] = None, 00085 stop_fitness: Optional[float] = -np.inf, 00086 keep: Optional[int] = 200, 00087 f: Optional[float] = 0.5, 00088 cr: Optional[float] = 0.9, 00089 rg: Optional[Generator] = Generator(PCG64DXSM()), 00090 filter = None, 00091 ints: Optional[ArrayLike] = None, 00092 min_mutate: Optional[float] = 0.1, 00093 max_mutate: Optional[float] = 0.5, 00094 modifier: Optional[Callable] = None) -> OptimizeResult: 00095 """ 00096 Minimize an objective function using the Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm. 00097 00098 This function optimizes a given objective function using the DE algorithm, which is 00099 a population-based metaheuristic optimization technique. It iteratively improves a 00100 population of potential solutions based on mutation, crossover, and selection 00101 strategies until a stopping criterion is met. The user can define various parameters 00102 to customize the behavior of the optimization process. 00103 00104 Args: 00105 fun: The objective function to be minimized, which takes a single argument 00106 (a candidate solution) and returns a scalar value representing its fitness. 00107 dim: Optional, number of dimensions of the input solution vector. If not 00108 provided, it will be inferred from `bounds`. 00109 bounds: Optional, bounds for each dimension of the input solution represented 00110 as a sequence of (min, max) tuples. It defines the permissible search space. 00111 popsize: Optional, population size for the DE algorithm. Determines the number 00112 of candidate solutions in each iteration. Default is 31. 00113 max_evaluations: Optional, maximum number of fitness evaluations allowed for 00114 the optimization process. Default is 100000. 00115 workers: Optional, number of parallel workers for evaluations. If set to more 00116 than 1, evaluations will be performed in parallel. If None or 1, sequential 00117 evaluation will be used. Default is None. 00118 stop_fitness: Optional, fitness value at which optimization will stop early. 00119 If a solution with fitness below this value is found, the optimization 00120 terminates. Default is -infinity. 00121 keep: Optional, defines how many solutions to retain for rebounded sampling. 00122 Default is 200. 00123 f: Optional, scale factor used to control mutation in the DE algorithm. Default 00124 is 0.5. 00125 cr: Optional, crossover rate used to control recombination in the DE algorithm. 00126 Default is 0.9. 00127 rg: Optional, random number generator used for stochastic components in the DE 00128 algorithm. Default is Generator(PCG64DXSM()). 00129 filter: Optional, a function to filter and validate solutions generated during 00130 the optimization process. 00131 ints: Optional, an array-like structure specifying indices of dimensions that 00132 should be treated as integers. 00133 min_mutate: Optional, minimum mutation factor for the DE mutation strategy. 00134 Default is 0.1. 00135 max_mutate: Optional, maximum mutation factor for the DE mutation strategy. 00136 Default is 0.5. 00137 modifier: Optional, a custom function to modify the behavior of the DE 00138 algorithm during optimization. 00139 00140 Returns: 00141 OptimizeResult: An object containing the optimization results: 00142 - x: The best solution found. 00143 - fun: The objective function value corresponding to `x`. 00144 - nfev: The total number of function evaluations performed. 00145 - nit: The number of iterations completed. 00146 - status: An integer indicating why the optimization stopped. A positive 00147 value represents success. 00148 - success: A boolean indicating whether the optimization was successful. 00149 00150 Raises: 00151 Exception: If any fatal error occurs during optimization, the function will 00152 return an OptimizeResult object with `success` set to False. 00153 """ 00154 00155 00156 de = DE(dim, bounds, popsize, stop_fitness, keep, f, cr, rg, filter, ints, 00157 min_mutate, max_mutate, modifier) 00158 try: 00159 if workers and workers > 1: 00160 x, val, evals, iterations, stop = de.do_optimize_delayed_update(fun, max_evaluations, workers) 00161 else: 00162 x, val, evals, iterations, stop = de.do_optimize(fun, max_evaluations) 00163 return OptimizeResult(x=x, fun=val, nfev=evals, nit=iterations, status=stop, 00164 success=True) 00165 except Exception as ex: 00166 return OptimizeResult(x=None, fun=sys.float_info.max, nfev=0, nit=0, status=-1, success=False) 00167 00168 class DE(object): 00169 """A Differential Evolution (DE) optimization algorithm. 00170 00171 This class implements a stochastic optimization algorithm called Differential 00172 Evolution. It is designed for solving optimization problems over continuous 00173 domains. The algorithm generates a population of candidate solutions and 00174 iteratively improves upon them using operations inspired by natural evolution. 00175 00176 Attributes: 00177 dim (int): Dimensionality of the problem space. 00178 lower (np.ndarray): Lower bounds for the problem space. 00179 upper (np.ndarray): Upper bounds for the problem space. 00180 popsize (int): Size of the population. 00181 stop_fitness (float): Early stopping criterion based on fitness value. 00182 keep (int): Number of iterations to preserve local improvements. 00183 rg (Generator): Random number generator for sampling operations. 00184 F0 (float): Differential weight. 00185 Cr0 (float): Crossover probability. 00186 stop (int): Termination condition flag. 00187 iterations (int): Number of completed iterations. 00188 evals (int): Number of function evaluations performed. 00189 p (int): Current index for population members. 00190 improves (collections.deque): Queue of improvement candidates observed in 00191 recent iterations. 00192 filter (Optional): Optional filter for evaluating candidate solutions. 00193 ints (np.ndarray): Array indicating integer-constrained dimensions. 00194 min_mutate (float): Minimum mutation factor. 00195 max_mutate (float): Maximum mutation factor. 00196 best_x (np.ndarray): Best solution vector found so far. 00197 best_value (float): Fitness value of the best solution. 00198 best_i (int): Index of the best solution in the population. 00199 pop_iter (np.ndarray): Array storing the iteration at which each member 00200 was last updated. 00201 x (np.ndarray): Current population of candidate solutions. 00202 x0 (np.ndarray): Previous population of candidate solutions. 00203 y (np.ndarray): Fitness values of the current population. 00204 """ 00205 def __init__(self, 00206 dim: int, 00207 bounds: Bounds, 00208 popsize: Optional[int] = 31, 00209 stop_fitness: Optional[float] = -np.inf, 00210 keep: Optional[int] = 200, 00211 F: Optional[float] = 0.5, 00212 Cr: Optional[float] = 0.9, 00213 rg: Optional[Generator] = Generator(PCG64DXSM()), 00214 filter: Optional = None, 00215 ints: Optional[ArrayLike] = None, 00216 min_mutate: Optional[float] = 0.1, 00217 max_mutate: Optional[float] = 0.5, 00218 modifier: Optional[Callable] = None): 00219 """ 00220 Initializes the optimizer with the specified parameters and configurations. This class is 00221 designed to manage and operate on populations of candidate solutions using specified rules 00222 and modifiers. It supports constraints like integer variables and bounds, and provides 00223 features such as mutation settings, filtering, and random number generation control. 00224 00225 Args: 00226 dim (int): Dimensionality of the problem (number of variables to be optimized). 00227 bounds (Bounds): An object specifying the lower and upper bounds for the variables. 00228 popsize (Optional[int]): Size of the population to be evolved. Default is 31. 00229 stop_fitness (Optional[float]): Stopping criterion based on fitness value. Default is -inf. 00230 keep (Optional[int]): Maximum number of generations to be stored for tracking. Default is 200. 00231 F (Optional[float]): Differential weight for mutation. Default is 0.5. 00232 Cr (Optional[float]): Crossover probability. Default is 0.9. 00233 rg (Optional[Generator]): Random number generator for stochastic operations. Default 00234 is `Generator(PCG64DXSM())`. 00235 filter (Optional): Custom filter to apply on solutions during evolution. Default is None. 00236 ints (Optional[ArrayLike]): Indices of integer variables in the solution. Default is None. 00237 min_mutate (Optional[float]): Minimum mutation value used for specific mutation rules. 00238 Default is 0.1. 00239 max_mutate (Optional[float]): Maximum mutation value applied during evolution. 00240 Default is 0.5. 00241 modifier (Optional[Callable]): A custom variable modifier function applied during evolution. 00242 If None and `ints` is not None, a default integer modifier is used. Default is None. 00243 """ 00244 self.dim, self.lower, self.upper = _check_bounds(bounds, dim) 00245 if popsize is None: 00246 popsize = 31 00247 self.popsize = popsize 00248 self.stop_fitness = stop_fitness 00249 self.keep = keep 00250 self.rg = rg 00251 self.F0 = F 00252 self.Cr0 = Cr 00253 self.stop = 0 00254 self.iterations = 0 00255 self.evals = 0 00256 self.p = 0 00257 self.improves = deque() 00258 self.filter = filter 00259 self.ints = np.array(ints) 00260 self.min_mutate = min_mutate 00261 self.max_mutate = max_mutate 00262 # use default variable modifier for int variables if modifier is None 00263 if modifier is None and not ints is None: 00264 self.lower = self.lower.astype(float) 00265 self.upper = self.upper.astype(float) 00266 self.modifier = self._modifier 00267 else: 00268 self.modifier = modifier 00269 self._init() 00270 if is_debug_active(): 00271 self.best_y = mp.RawValue(ct.c_double, 1E99) 00272 self.n_evals = mp.RawValue(ct.c_long, 0) 00273 self.time_0 = time() 00274 00275 def ask(self) -> np.ndarray: 00276 """ 00277 Generates and returns the next set of samples to be evaluated based on the evolutionary strategy. 00278 00279 The method ensures that all individuals in the population either utilize previously identified 00280 improvements or are generated as new samples. If improvements are queued, they are integrated 00281 into the population. Otherwise, new samples are generated for population members. 00282 00283 Returns: 00284 np.ndarray: An array containing the generated or improved samples for the entire population. 00285 """ 00286 00287 xs = [None] * self.popsize 00288 for _ in range(self.popsize): 00289 if self.improves: 00290 p, x = self.improves[0] 00291 if xs[p] is None: 00292 xs[p] = x 00293 self.improves.popleft() 00294 else: 00295 break 00296 else: 00297 break 00298 for p in range(self.popsize): 00299 if xs[p] is None: 00300 _, _, xs[p] = self._next_x(p) 00301 self.asked = xs 00302 return xs 00303 00304 def tell(self, 00305 ys:ArrayLike, 00306 xs:Optional[ArrayLike] = None) -> int: 00307 00308 """ 00309 Tells the algorithm about the function evaluations (objective values) for the proposed 00310 solutions and updates the state accordingly. 00311 00312 This method is used to inform the algorithm of the results of one or more objective 00313 function evaluations. This information is essential for the algorithm to proceed 00314 with the optimization process and adjust its internal model or state. 00315 00316 Args: 00317 ys (ArrayLike): Array of function evaluation results (objective values) 00318 corresponding to the proposed solutions. 00319 xs (Optional[ArrayLike]): Array of proposed solutions for which the objective 00320 values (ys) have been evaluated. If not provided, the method will use 00321 solutions that were previously "asked" by the algorithm. 00322 00323 Returns: 00324 int: An integer indicating the stop condition of the optimization process. 00325 """ 00326 00327 if xs is None: 00328 xs = self.asked 00329 self.evals += len(ys) 00330 for p in range(len(ys)): 00331 self.tell_one(p, ys[p], xs[p]) 00332 return self.stop 00333 00334 def population(self) -> np.ndarray: 00335 """ 00336 Retrieves the population data stored in the class. 00337 00338 The method returns the population data, which is stored in the object's state. It is expected 00339 to be a NumPy array representing specific data related to the population. 00340 00341 Returns: 00342 np.ndarray: The population data stored in the object. 00343 """ 00344 return self.x 00345 00346 def result(self) -> OptimizeResult: 00347 """ 00348 Returns an optimization result object containing the final outcome of the 00349 optimization process. 00350 00351 This method encapsulates the key output data in an `OptimizeResult` object, 00352 providing details about the best solution found during the optimization, 00353 the function value at that solution, the total number of function evaluations, 00354 the number of iterations performed, and the status of the optimizer. 00355 00356 Returns: 00357 OptimizeResult: An object containing the results of the optimization process, 00358 including details such as the optimal solution (`x`), the objective function 00359 value at that solution (`fun`), total function evaluations (`nfev`), 00360 number of iterations (`nit`), the stopping status (`status`), and a success 00361 flag (`success`). 00362 """ 00363 return OptimizeResult(x=self.best_x, fun=self.best_value, 00364 nfev=self.iterations*self.popsize, 00365 nit=self.iterations, status=self.stop, success=True) 00366 00367 def ask_one(self) -> Tuple[int, np.ndarray]: 00368 """ 00369 Generates the next candidate from the population queue or computes a new one. 00370 00371 This function retrieves the next candidate solution for evaluation. If pre-generated 00372 candidates are available in the queue (`self.improves`), it dequeues one. Otherwise, 00373 it computes a new candidate based on the current population index. 00374 00375 Returns: 00376 Tuple[int, np.ndarray]: A tuple where the first element is the population index 00377 of the candidate, and the second element is the candidate solution in the form 00378 of a numpy array. 00379 00380 Raises: 00381 No explicit exceptions are raised by this method. 00382 """ 00383 00384 if self.improves: 00385 p, x = self.improves.popleft() 00386 else: 00387 p = self.p 00388 _, _, x = self._next_x(p) 00389 self.p = (self.p + 1) % self.popsize 00390 return p, x 00391 00392 def tell_one(self, p: int, y:float , x:ArrayLike) -> int: 00393 """ 00394 Process a single individual's evaluation update within a population-based optimization 00395 algorithm. Updates the values of the provided population member based on the fitness 00396 of the given evaluation and decides whether to replace it with a new candidate. Tracks 00397 improvements and adjusts population state as necessary. 00398 00399 Args: 00400 p (int): Index of the population member to update. 00401 y (float): Evaluated fitness value of the candidate solution. 00402 x (ArrayLike): Candidate solution corresponding to the evaluated fitness. 00403 00404 Returns: 00405 int: Indicator for whether the optimization should stop (1 for stop, 0 for continue). 00406 """ 00407 00408 if not self.filter is None: 00409 self.filter.add(x, y) 00410 00411 if (self.y[p] > y): 00412 # temporal locality 00413 if self.iterations > 1: 00414 self.improves.append((p, self._next_improve(self.x[self.best_i], x, self.x0[p]))) 00415 self.x0[p] = self.x[p] 00416 self.x[p] = x 00417 self.y[p] = y 00418 if self.y[self.best_i] > y: 00419 self.best_i = p 00420 if self.best_value > y: 00421 self.best_x = x 00422 self.best_value = y 00423 if self.stop_fitness > y: 00424 self.stop = 1 00425 self.pop_iter[p] = self.iterations 00426 else: 00427 if self.rg.uniform(0, self.keep) < self.iterations - self.pop_iter[p]: 00428 self.x[p] = self._sample() 00429 self.y[p] = np.inf 00430 00431 if is_debug_active(): 00432 self.n_evals.value += 1 00433 if y < self.best_y.value or self.n_evals.value % 1000 == 999: 00434 if y < self.best_y.value: self.best_y.value = y 00435 t = time() - self.time_0 + 1E-9 00436 c = self.n_evals.value 00437 message = '"c/t={0:.2f} c={1:d} t={2:.2f} y={3:.5f} yb={4:.5f} x={5!s}'.format( 00438 c/t, c, t, y, self.best_y.value, x) 00439 logger.debug(message) 00440 00441 return self.stop 00442 00443 def _init(self): 00444 """ 00445 Initializes the optimization population and sets up initial values. 00446 00447 This method initializes the population matrix and related attributes for an 00448 optimization problem. It samples the initial values for the population, assigns 00449 the initial objective values to infinity, and determines the placeholder for 00450 the best solution and its corresponding value. 00451 00452 Attributes: 00453 x (ndarray): The population matrix of shape (popsize, dim), where each row 00454 represents an individual solution in the population. 00455 x0 (ndarray): A matrix of the initial population, identical to `x` at this 00456 stage. 00457 y (ndarray): Array of objective values for each individual in the 00458 population. 00459 best_x (ndarray): Best solution found so far, initialized with the first 00460 individual of the population. 00461 best_value (float): Objective value of the best solution found so far, 00462 initialized to infinity. 00463 best_i (int): Index of the current best solution in the population, 00464 initialized to 0. 00465 pop_iter (ndarray): Array to track the iteration or generation count for 00466 each individual in the population. 00467 """ 00468 self.x = np.zeros((self.popsize, self.dim)) 00469 self.x0 = np.zeros((self.popsize, self.dim)) 00470 self.y = np.empty(self.popsize) 00471 for i in range(self.popsize): 00472 self.x[i] = self.x0[i] = self._sample() 00473 self.y[i] = np.inf 00474 self.best_x = self.x[0] 00475 self.best_value = np.inf 00476 self.best_i = 0 00477 self.pop_iter = np.zeros(self.popsize) 00478 00479 def apply_fun(self, x, x_old, y_old): 00480 """ 00481 Applies the function to the input or returns a default fallback based on a filter. 00482 00483 This method evaluates the given function `fun` for the input `x`. If a `filter` 00484 is present, it checks the `filter` criteria to determine if the evaluation 00485 should proceed. If the criteria are met, it applies the function and adds 00486 the result to the filter, otherwise it returns a predefined fallback value 00487 (1E99). If no `filter` exists, the function is always evaluated. 00488 00489 Args: 00490 x: The current input to the function `fun` to be evaluated. 00491 x_old: The previous input value in the process for comparison in the 00492 filter. 00493 y_old: The previous output value in the process for comparison in the 00494 filter. 00495 00496 Returns: 00497 The result of evaluating the function `fun(x)` if no filter exists or the 00498 filter criteria are fulfilled. Otherwise, returns the fallback value 00499 1E99. 00500 """ 00501 if self.filter is None: 00502 self.evals += 1 00503 return self.fun(x) 00504 else: 00505 if self.filter.is_improve(x, x_old, y_old): 00506 self.evals += 1 00507 y = self.fun(x) 00508 self.filter.add(x, y) 00509 return y 00510 else: 00511 return 1E99 00512 00513 def do_optimize(self, fun, max_evals): 00514 """ 00515 Optimizes a given objective function using a population-based strategy. The optimization process is based on 00516 iterative improvements of candidate solutions to minimize the objective function value. 00517 00518 Args: 00519 fun: Callable 00520 The objective function to be minimized. Must accept input vectors resembling the solution 00521 representation. 00522 max_evals: int 00523 The maximum number of function evaluations allowed during the optimization process. 00524 00525 Returns: 00526 Tuple 00527 A tuple containing the following: 00528 - best_x: Array or list representing the best solution found during the optimization. 00529 - best_value: float, the value of the objective function for the best solution. 00530 - evals: int, the total number of function evaluations performed. 00531 - iterations: int, the total number of iterations completed during the optimization process. 00532 - stop: int, an indicator explaining the stop condition (e.g., termination criteria met). 00533 """ 00534 self.fun = fun 00535 self.max_evals = max_evals 00536 self.iterations = 0 00537 self.evals = 0 00538 while self.evals < self.max_evals: 00539 for p in range(self.popsize): 00540 xb, xi, x = self._next_x(p) 00541 y = self.apply_fun(x, xi, self.y[p]) 00542 if y < self.y[p]: 00543 # temporal locality 00544 if self.iterations > 1: 00545 x2 = self._next_improve(xb, x, xi) 00546 y2 = self.apply_fun(x2, x, y) 00547 if y2 < y: 00548 y = y2 00549 x = x2 00550 self.x[p] = x 00551 self.y[p] = y 00552 self.pop_iter[p] = self.iterations 00553 if y < self.y[self.best_i]: 00554 self.best_i = p; 00555 if y < self.best_value: 00556 self.best_value = y; 00557 self.best_x = x; 00558 if self.stop_fitness > y: 00559 self.stop = 1 00560 else: 00561 # reinitialize individual 00562 if self.rg.uniform(0, self.keep) < self.iterations - self.pop_iter[p]: 00563 self.x[p] = self._sample() 00564 self.y[p] = np.inf 00565 if self.evals >= self.max_evals: 00566 break 00567 00568 return self.best_x, self.best_value, self.evals, self.iterations, self.stop 00569 00570 def do_optimize_delayed_update(self, fun, max_evals, workers=mp.cpu_count()): 00571 """ 00572 Performs a delayed update optimization process using multiple workers for 00573 parallel evaluation. The method initializes workers, evaluates population 00574 solutions, and determines the best solution through iterated queries 00575 and evaluations. 00576 00577 Args: 00578 fun: Callable function to be optimized. 00579 max_evals: Maximum number of function evaluations to perform. 00580 workers: Integer specifying the number of workers for parallel 00581 execution. Defaults to the number of available CPU cores. 00582 00583 Returns: 00584 A tuple containing: 00585 - best_x: The best solution found during the optimization process. 00586 - best_value: The objective function value corresponding to the 00587 best solution. 00588 - evals: The total number of evaluations performed. 00589 - iterations: The number of optimization iterations completed. 00590 - stop: An integer representing the stopping criterion met. 00591 """ 00592 self.fun = fun 00593 self.max_evals = max_evals 00594 evaluator = Evaluator(self.fun) 00595 evaluator.start(workers) 00596 evals_x = {} 00597 self.iterations = 0 00598 self.evals = 0 00599 self.p = 0 00600 self.improves = deque() 00601 for _ in range(workers): # fill queue with initial population 00602 p, x = self.ask_one() 00603 evaluator.pipe[0].send((self.evals, x)) 00604 evals_x[self.evals] = p, x # store x 00605 self.evals += 1 00606 00607 while True: # read from pipe, tell de and create new x 00608 evals, y = evaluator.pipe[0].recv() 00609 p, x = evals_x[evals] # retrieve evaluated x 00610 del evals_x[evals] 00611 self.tell_one(p, y, x) # tell evaluated x 00612 if self.stop != 0 or self.evals >= self.max_evals: 00613 break # shutdown worker if stop criteria met 00614 00615 for _ in range(workers): 00616 p, x = self.ask_one() # create new x 00617 if self.filter is None or \ 00618 self.filter.is_improve(x, self.x[p], self.y[p]): 00619 break 00620 evaluator.pipe[0].send((self.evals, x)) 00621 evals_x[self.evals] = p, x # store x 00622 self.evals += 1 00623 00624 evaluator.stop() 00625 return self.best_x, self.best_value, self.evals, self.iterations, self.stop 00626 00627 def _next_x(self, p): 00628 """ 00629 Determines the next vector in an evolutionary computation process. 00630 00631 This method calculates a new candidate vector based on differential 00632 evolution principles. If a predefined number of iterations has been 00633 reached and the process is in even iterations, certain parameters 00634 (Cr and F) are halved. Random indices are selected to generate a 00635 mutation vector, ensuring the indices do not overlap with the 00636 current or best vector. A trial vector is then computed using a 00637 crossover operation. 00638 00639 Args: 00640 p: int 00641 Index of the current vector in the population. 00642 00643 Returns: 00644 tuple: 00645 Contains the best vector (xb), the current vector (xp), 00646 and the newly generated vector (x). 00647 """ 00648 if p == 0: 00649 self.iterations += 1 00650 self.Cr = 0.5*self.Cr0 if self.iterations % 2 == 0 else self.Cr0 00651 self.F = 0.5*self.F0 if self.iterations % 2 == 0 else self.F0 00652 while True: 00653 r1, r2 = self.rg.integers(0, self.popsize, 2) 00654 if r1 != p and r1 != self.best_i and r1 != r2 \ 00655 and r2 != p and r2 != self.best_i: 00656 break 00657 xp = self.x[p] 00658 xb = self.x[self.best_i] 00659 x1 = self.x[r1] 00660 x2 = self.x[r2] 00661 x = self._feasible(xb + self.F * (x1 - x2)) 00662 r = self.rg.integers(0, self.dim) 00663 tr = np.array( 00664 [i != r and self.rg.random() > self.Cr for i in range(self.dim)]) 00665 x[tr] = xp[tr] 00666 if not self.modifier is None: 00667 x = self.modifier(x) 00668 return xb, xp, x 00669 00670 def _next_improve(self, xb, x, xi): 00671 """ 00672 Compute the next feasible point to improve optimization. 00673 00674 This method adjusts the provided point to ensure it meets feasibility 00675 criteria and optionally applies a modifier to the point before returning. 00676 00677 Args: 00678 xb: The base point for the improvement computation. 00679 x: The current point to be adjusted. 00680 xi: The initial guess or reference point for adjustment. 00681 00682 Returns: 00683 The next feasible point after adjustment and optional modification. 00684 """ 00685 x = self._feasible(xb + ((x - xi) * 0.5)) 00686 if not self.modifier is None: 00687 x = self.modifier(x) 00688 return x 00689 00690 def _sample(self): 00691 """ 00692 Generates a sample from the specified distribution. 00693 00694 If the `upper` attribute is not set, a random sample is drawn from a normal 00695 distribution. Otherwise, a sample is generated from a uniform distribution 00696 bounded by the `lower` and `upper` attributes. Optionally, a modifier function 00697 can be applied to the generated value before returning it. 00698 00699 Returns: 00700 float: A random sample from the specified distribution. If a modifier 00701 function is applied, the modified value is returned. 00702 """ 00703 if self.upper is None: 00704 return self.rg.normal() 00705 else: 00706 x = self.rg.uniform(self.lower, self.upper) 00707 if not self.modifier is None: 00708 x = self.modifier(x) 00709 return x 00710 00711 def _feasible(self, x): 00712 """ 00713 Checks the feasibility of a value with respect to specified bounds and adjusts it 00714 if necessary by clipping it to the range defined by the lower and upper bounds. 00715 00716 Args: 00717 x: The value to check and potentially adjust. 00718 00719 Returns: 00720 The original value if it lies within the bounds or a clipped value adjusted 00721 to satisfy the bounds if it falls outside the range. 00722 """ 00723 if self.upper is None: 00724 return x 00725 else: 00726 return np.clip(x, self.lower, self.upper) 00727 00728 # default modifier for integer variables 00729 def _modifier(self, x): 00730 """ 00731 Modifies integer elements of the input array based on mutation probability. 00732 00733 This method mutates specific elements of the input array, which are 00734 specified by the attribute `ints`. Mutation is governed by random values 00735 generated within the range defined by `min_mutate` and `max_mutate`. 00736 The mutated values lie within the bounds specified by `lower` and `upper`. 00737 00738 Args: 00739 x (np.ndarray): Input array containing elements to mutate. 00740 00741 Returns: 00742 np.ndarray: Mutated version of the input array. 00743 """ 00744 x_ints = x[self.ints] 00745 n_ints = len(self.ints) 00746 lb = self.lower[self.ints] 00747 ub = self.upper[self.ints] 00748 to_mutate = self.rg.uniform(self.min_mutate, self.max_mutate) 00749 # mututate some integer variables 00750 x[self.ints] = np.array([x if self.rg.random() > to_mutate/n_ints else 00751 int(self.rg.uniform(lb[i], ub[i])) 00752 for i, x in enumerate(x_ints)]) 00753 return x 00754 00755 def _check_bounds(bounds, dim): 00756 """ 00757 Validates and processes the input bounds and dimensions for subsequent operations. 00758 00759 This function ensures that either `bounds` or `dim` is provided and determines the valid 00760 dimensionality and boundary arrays for further processing. If `bounds` is None, the 00761 function uses the provided `dim`. Otherwise, it extracts and converts the lower and 00762 upper bounds arrays from `bounds`. 00763 00764 Args: 00765 bounds: User-provided object containing boundary attributes (`lb` and `ub`) 00766 for dimensional constraints. Can be None if `dim` is specified. 00767 dim: An integer defining the dimensionality, used only if `bounds` is None. 00768 00769 Returns: 00770 Tuple comprising: 00771 - An integer representing the number of dimensions (from `bounds` or `dim`). 00772 - A numpy array of lower boundary values (`bounds.lb`) if provided; otherwise None. 00773 - A numpy array of upper boundary values (`bounds.ub`) if provided; otherwise None. 00774 00775 Raises: 00776 ValueError: If both `bounds` and `dim` are None. 00777 """ 00778 if bounds is None and dim is None: 00779 raise ValueError('either dim or bounds need to be defined') 00780 if bounds is None: 00781 return dim, None, None 00782 else: 00783 return len(bounds.ub), np.asarray(bounds.lb), np.asarray(bounds.ub) 00784 00785
